    9. 9
      Maramai, S.; Benchekroun, M.; Gabr, M. T.; Yahiaoui, S. Multitarget therapeutic strategies for Alzheimer’s disease: review on emerging target combinations. BioMed Res. Int. 2020, 2020, 5120230,  DOI: 10.1155/2020/5120230
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Multitarget Therapeutic Strategies for Alzheimer's Disease: Review on Emerging Target Combinations
      Maramai Samuele; Benchekroun Mohamed; Gabr Moustafa T; Yahiaoui Samir
      BioMed research international (2020), 2020 (), 5120230 ISSN:.
      Neurodegenerative diseases represent nowadays one of the major health problems. Despite the efforts made to unveil the mechanism leading to neurodegeneration, it is still not entirely clear what triggers this phenomenon and what allows its progression. Nevertheless, it is accepted that neurodegeneration is a consequence of several detrimental processes, such as protein aggregation, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation, finally resulting in the loss of neuronal functions. Starting from these evidences, there has been a wide search for novel agents able to address more than a single event at the same time, the so-called multitarget-directed ligands (MTDLs). These compounds originated from the combination of different pharmacophoric elements which endowed them with the ability to interfere with different enzymatic and/or receptor systems, or to exert neuroprotective effects by modulating proteins and metal homeostasis. MTDLs have been the focus of the latest strategies to discover a new treatment for Alzheimer's disease (AD), which is considered the most common form of dementia characterized by neurodegeneration and cognitive dysfunctions. This review is aimed at collecting the latest and most interesting target combinations for the treatment of AD, with a detailed discussion on new agents with favorable in vitro properties and on optimized structures that have already been assessed in vivo in animal models of dementia.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB38jnsVOgtA%253D%253D&md5=ab46a4d0bdd352cadf2f0257ef40ac84

      Ghosal, S.; Bhattacharya, S.K.; Mehta, R. Naturally occurring and synthetic β-carbolines as cholinesterase inhibitors. J. Pharm. Sci. 1972, 61, 808– 810,  DOI: 10.1002/jps.2600610535
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Naturally occurring and synthetic β-carbolines as cholinesterase inhibitors
      Ghosal, S.; Bhattacharya, S. K.; Mehta, R.
      Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (1972), 61 (5), 808-10CODEN: JPMSAE; ISSN:0022-3549.
      The inhibitory activities of a no. of naturally occurring and synthetic aromatic and tetrahydro-β-carbolines toward true cholinesterases [9001-08-5] and pseudocholinesterases [9001-08-5] were detd. Some quaternary aromatic β-carbolines such as 3-methylindolo[2,3-c]pyridinium (I) [17994-14-8] had .sim.1/6th the in vitro anticholinesterase activity of physostigmine [57-47-6]. The tertiary aromatic β-carbolines tested such as pyrido[3,4-b]indole [244-63-3] had only weak activity and the tetrahydro-β-carbolines tested were inactive. Structure-activity relations involved in the anticholinesterase activity of β-carbolines were discussed.

      Otto, R.; Penzis, R.; Gaube, F.; Winckler, T.; Appenroth, D.; Fleck, C.; Tränkle, C.; Lehmann, J.; Enzensperger, C. Beta and gamma carboline derivatives as potential anti-Alzheimer agents: a comparison. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2014, 87, 63– 70,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2014.09.048
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Beta and gamma carboline derivatives as potential anti-Alzheimer agents: A comparison
      Otto, Robert; Penzis, Robert; Gaube, Friedemann; Winckler, Thomas; Appenroth, Dorothea; Fleck, Christian; Traenkle, Christian; Lehmann, Jochen; Enzensperger, Christoph
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 87 (), 63-70CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      Nine novel β- and γ-carboline derivs. bearing either methyl-, propargyl- or phenethyl-residues at the indole nitrogen were synthesized and tested as potential anti-Alzheimer drugs. Antagonism of recombinantly expressed NMDA receptors, inhibition of cholinesterases, and radical scavenging properties were detd. for all compds. Some were addnl. tested in vivo for their ability to reverse scopolamine-induced cognitive impairment in an 8-arm radial maze expt. with rats. For the most promising candidates, the interaction with muscarinic M1 receptors was also investigated. With this set of compds. assays the influence of the scaffold itself and the substituents can be investigated sep. 5-Methyl-γ-carboline (I) was the most potent (0.25 μmol/100 g b.w.) compd. in the in vivo test and might be a good starting point for the development of novel anti-Alzheimer drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFOlsLzM&md5=d12fd4e4f527b4fe894e9aa80dd361cc
    12. 12
      Filali, I.; Bouajila, J.; Znati, M.; Bousejra-El Garah, F.; Ben Jannet, H. Synthesis of new isoxazoline derivatives from harmine and evaluation of their anti-Alzheimer, anti-cancer and anti-inflammatory activities. J. Enzyme Inhib. Med.       [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Synthesis of new isoxazoline derivatives from harmine and evaluation of their anti-Alzheimer, anti-cancer and anti-inflammatory activities
      Filali, Insaf; Bouajila, Jalloul; Znati, Mansour; Bousejra-El Garah, Fatima; Ben Jannet, Hichem
      Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 30 (3), 371-376CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Informa Healthcare)
      A series of new harmine derivs. has been prepd. by cycloaddn. reaction using various arylnitrile oxides and evaluated in vitro against acetylcholinesterase and 5-lipoxygenase enzymes, MCF7 and HCT116 cancer cell lines. Some of these mols. have been shown to be potent inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase and MCF7 cell line. The greatest activity against acetylcholinesterase (IC50 = 10.4 μM) was obtained for harmine and cytotoxic activities (IC50 = 0.2 μM) for compd. I. Two derivs. with the thiophene and furan systems, resp., showed good activity against 5-lipoxygenase enzyme (IC50 = 29.2 and 55.5 μM, resp.).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFGlsbrP&md5=f6abdf9bdc760dafab6280d7500bdabb
    13. 13
      Filali, I.; Belkacem, M. A.; Ben Nejma, A.; Souchard, J.-P.; Ben Jannet, H.; Bouajila, J. Synthesis, cytotoxic, anti-lipoxygenase and anti-acetylcholinesterase capacities of novel derivatives from harmine. J. Enzyme Inhib. Med. Chem. 2016, 31, 23– 33,  DOI: 10.3109/14756366.2016.1163342
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Synthesis, cytotoxic, anti-lipoxygenase and anti-acetylcholinesterase capacities of novel derivatives from harmine
      Filali, Insaf; Belkacem, Mohamed Amine; Ben Nejma, Aymen; Souchard, Jean Pierre; Ben Jannet, Hichem; Bouajila, Jalloul
      Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2016), 31 (sup1), 23-33CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      We synthesized two series of new hydrazide harmine derivs. The reaction of harmine (I; R = H) with Et acetate chloride afforded the corresponding Et ester I (R = CH2CO2Et). The treatment of with hydrazine hydrate gave the hydrazide I (R = CH2CONHNH2) which further converted into hydrazones I [R = CH2CONHN:CHAr; Ar = C6H4(Bu-t)-4, C6H4(NMe2)-4, C6H3(OMe)2-3,4, C6H4(CF2CHF2)-4, C6H4(SMe)-4, C6H4OMe-4, C6H3Cl-4-NO2-3, C6H4CHO-4, quinolin-6-yl, C6H4(morpholin-4-yl)-4] and dihydrazides II (Z = Z1, Z2, NHCO(CH2)2CO2H). A series of new triazoles III [R' = H, Me, OMe, Cl, Et, NO2] has also been prepd. from the suitable propargylharmine I (R = CH2C≡CH). The synthesized derivs. were characterized by 1H-NMR, 13C-NMR, and HRMS and evaluated for their activities against MCF7, HCT116 OVCAR-3, acetylcholinesterase and 5-lipoxygenase. The hydrazones derivs. I [R = CH2CONHN:CHAr] have a good cytotoxic activity against all cell lines, while I [R = CH2CONHN:CHAr; Ar = C6H4(CMe3)-4, C6H4CF2CHF2, C6H4OMe-4, C6H3Cl-4-NO2-3] are more active than harmine (against OVCAR-3 IC50 16.7-2.5 μM). The compd. I (R = CH2C≡CH) was the most active (IC50 = 1.9 μM) against acetylcholinesterase. Some compds. exhibited significant activity against 5-lipoxygenase (IC50 = 30.9-63.1 μM).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XltlSrt7w%253D&md5=290f03b99a12853a936f77ab220aad0b
    14. 14
      Khorana, N.; Changwichit, K.; Ingkaninan, K.; Utsintong, M. Prospective acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity of indole and its analogs. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2012, 22, 2885– 2888,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2012.02.057
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      Prospective acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity of indole and its analogs
      Khorana, Nantaka; Changwichit, Kanokwan; Ingkaninan, Kornkanok; Utsintong, Maleeruk
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2012), 22 (8), 2885-2888CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitory activity is one of the proposed targets for indole analogs. Simple indoles with substitution of methoxy, carboxy or hydroxy at the benzene ring showed a low percent of inhibitory activity in eel-AChE. Adding a side chain at the pyrrole ring, such as serotonin, β-carbolines and quinolines (the bioisostere of indole), improved the inhibitory activity significantly. However, proper substitution and conformation of the ring were required for good binding. The result of inhibition in human-AChE of serotonin, β-carbolines and quinolines showed similar profile as eel-AChE with lower magnitude. The data from mol. docking showed that they shared the same binding site as galantamine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XktFSiur0%253D&md5=6a176945ba442c4495e141af23cd1563
    15. 15
      Zhao, T.; Ding, K.; Zhang, L.; Cheng, X.; Wang, C.; Wang, Z. Acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase inhibitory activities of β-carboline and quinoline alkaloids derivatives from the plants of genus Peganum. J. Chem. 2013, 717232
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase inhibitory activities of β-carboline and quinoline alkaloids derivatives from the plants of genus Peganum
      Zhao, Ting; Ding, Ke-Min; Zhang, Lei; Cheng, Xue-Mei; Wang, Chang-Hong; Wang, Zheng-Tao
      Journal of Chemistry (2013), (), 717232, 6 pp.CODEN: JCOHD5; ISSN:2090-9071. (Hindawi Publishing Corp.)
      It was reported that the main chem. constituents in plants of genus Peganum were a serial of β-carboline and quinoline alkaloids. These alkaloids were quant. assessed for selective inhibitory activities on acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) by in vitro Ellman method. The results indicated that harmane was the most potent selective AChE inhibitor with an IC50 of 7.11 ± 2.00 μM and AChE selectivity index (SI, IC50 of BChE/IC50 of AChE) of 10.82. Vasicine was the most potent BChE inhibitor with feature of dual AChE/BChE inhibitory activity, with an IC50 vs. AChE/BChE of 13.68 ± 1.25/2.60 ± 1.47 μM and AChE SI of 0.19. By analyzing and comparing the IC50 and SI of those chems., it was indicated that the β-carboline alkaloids displayed more potent AChE inhibition but less BChE inhibition than quinoline alkaloids. The substituent at the C7 position of the β-carboline alkaloids and C3 and C9 positions of quinoline alkaloids played a crit. role in AChE or BChE inhibition. The potent inhibition suggested that those alkaloids may be used as candidates for treatment of Alzheimer's disease. The anal. of the quant. structure-activity relationship of those compds. investigated might provide guidance for the design and synthesis of AChE and BChE inhibitors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXksFCqsr4%253D&md5=fb2c67d9d109560c2d74a2b3cd766de8
    16. 16
      Liu, W.; Yang, Y.; Cheng, X.; Gong, C.; Li, S.; He, D.; Yang, L.; Wang, Z.; Wang, C. Rapid and sensitive detection of the inhibitive activities of acetyl- and butyryl-cholinesterases inhibitors by UPLC-ESI-MS/MS. J. Pharm. Biomed. Anal. 2014, 94, 215– 220,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpba.2014.02.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Rapid and sensitive detection of the inhibitive activities of acetyl- and butyryl-cholinesterases inhibitors by UPLC-ESI-MS/MS
      Liu, Wei; Yang, Yadi; Cheng, Xuemei; Gong, Can; Li, Shuping; He, Dandan; Yang, Li; Wang, Zhengtao; Wang, Changhong
      Journal of Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Analysis (2014), 94 (), 215-220CODEN: JPBADA; ISSN:0731-7085. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) are legitimate therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease. The classical approach for screening potential AChE/BChE inhibitors was developed by Ellman. However, the background color of compds. or plant exts. remained uncertain and frequently interfered with the detection of the secondary reaction, thereby easily yielding false pos. or false neg. results. Rapid, selective, and sensitive ultra-performance liq. chromatog. combined with electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry method was developed and used for the detection of AChE and BChE inhibition by directly detg. the common product, choline (Ch). Proper sepn. was achieved for choline and chlormequat (internal std.) within 1.2 min via isocratic elution (0.1% formic acid:methanol = 98:2) on an HSS T3 column following a simple pptn. of proteins for sample treatment. The relative std. deviations of the intra- and inter-day precisions were below 7.34 and 9.09%, resp., whereas the mean accuracy for the quality control samples was 100.31 ± 10.93%. The method exhibited the advantages of small total reaction vol. (100 μL), short anal. time (1.2 min), high sensitivity (LOQ of 0.036 μM for Ch), and low cost (little consumption enzymes of 0.0035 and 0.008 unit mL-1 for AChE and BChE, and substrates of 5.505 and 7.152 μM for ACh and BCh in individual inhibition, resp.), and without matrix effect (90.00-105.03%). The developed method was successfully applied for detecting the AChE and BChE inhibitive activities for model drugs, including galanthamine, tacrine, neostigmine methylsulfate, eserine, as well as β-carboline and quinazoline alkaloids from Peganum harmala.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXkslGmtbY%253D&md5=6923ec1a9b3044946f3460bd89c01480
    17. 17
      Liew, S. Y.; Khaw, K. Y.; Murugaiyah, V.; Looi, C. Y.; Wong, Y. L.; Mustafa, M. R.; Litaudon, M.; Awang, K. Natural indole butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors from Nauclea officinalis. Phytomedicine 2015, 22, 45– 48,  DOI: 10.1016/j.phymed.2014.11.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Natural indole butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors from Nauclea officinalis
      Liew, Sook Yee; Khaw, Kooi Yeong; Murugaiyah, Vikneswaran; Looi, Chung Yeng; Wong, Yi Li; Mustafa, Mohd Rais; Litaudon, Marc; Awang, Khalijah
      Phytomedicine (2015), 22 (1), 45-48CODEN: PYTOEY; ISSN:0944-7113. (Elsevier GmbH)
      Nine monoterpenoid indole alkaloids; naucletine (1), angustidine (2), nauclefine (3), angustine (4), naucline (5), angustoline (6), harmane (7), 3,14-dihydroangustoline (8), strictosamide (9) and one quinoline alkaloid glycoside; pumiloside (10) from Nauclea officinalis were tested for cholinesterase inhibitory activity. All the alkaloids except for pumiloside (10) showed strong to weak BChE inhibitory effect with IC50 values ranging between 1.02-168.55 μM. Angustidine (2), nauclefine (3), angustine (4), angustoline (6) and harmane (7) showed higher BChE inhibiting potency compared to galanthamine. Angustidine (2) was the most potent inhibitor towards both AChE and BChE. Mol. docking (MD) studies showed that angustidine (2) docked deep into the bottom gorge of hBChE and formed hydrogen bonding with Ser 198 and His 438. Kinetic study of angustidine (2) on BChE suggested a mixed inhibition mode with an inhibition const. (Ki) of 6.12 μM.

    18. 18
      Torres, J. M.; Lira, A. F.; Silva, D. R.; Guzzo, L. M.; Sant’Anna, C. M. R.; Kümmerle, A. E.; Rumjanek, V. M. Structural insights into cholinesterases inhibition by harmane β-carbolinium derivatives: a kinetics - molecular modeling approach. Phytochemistry 2012, 81, 24– 30,  DOI: 10.1016/j.phytochem.2012.05.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Structural insights into cholinesterases inhibition by harmane β-carbolinium derivatives: A kinetics - molecular modeling approach
      Torres, Juliana M.; Lira, Aline F.; Silva, Daniel R.; Guzzo, Lucas M.; Sant'Anna, Carlos M. R.; Kuemmerle, Arthur E.; Rumjanek, Victor M.
      Phytochemistry (Elsevier) (2012), 81 (), 24-30CODEN: PYTCAS; ISSN:0031-9422. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The natural indole alkaloids, the β-carbolines, are often assocd. with cholinesterase inhibition, esp. their quaternary salts, which frequently have higher activity than the free bases. Due to lack of information explaining this fact in the literature, the cholinesterase inhibition by the natural product harmane and its two β-carbolinium synthetic deriv. salts (N-Me and N-ethyl) was explored, together with a combination of kinetics and a mol. modeling approach. The results, mainly for the β-carbolinium salts, demonstrated a noncompetitive inhibition profile, ruling out previous findings which assocd. cholinesterase inhibition by β-carbolinium salts to a possible mimicking of the choline moiety of the natural substrate, acetylcholine. Mol. modeling studies corroborate this kind of inhibition through analyses of inhibitor/enzyme and inhibitor/substrate/enzyme complexes of both enzymes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFGltbbE&md5=e8ac9bf5e50ebd4e3fdd96f72ac16746
    19. 19
      Fadaeinasab, M.; Basiri, A.; Kia, Y.; Karimian, H.; Ali, H. M.; Murugaiyah, V. New indole alkaloids from the bark of Rauvolfia reflexa and their cholinesterase inhibitory activity. Cell. Physiol. Biochem. 2015, 37, 1997– 2011,  DOI: 10.1159/000438560
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      New Indole Alkaloids from the Bark of Rauvolfia Reflexa and their Cholinesterase Inhibitory Activity
      Fadaeinasab, Mehran; Basiri, Alireza; Kia, Yalda; Karimian, Hamed; Ali, Hapipah Mohd.; Murugaiyah, Vikneswaran
      Cellular Physiology and Biochemistry (2015), 37 (5), 1997-2011CODEN: CEPBEW; ISSN:1015-8987. (S. Karger AG)
      Background/Aims: Rauvolfia reflexa is a member of the Apocynaceae family. Plants from the Apocynaceae family have been traditionally used in the treatment of age-related brain disorders Methods and Results: Two new indole alkaloids, rauvolfine C (1) and 3-methyl-10,11-dimethoxy-6-methoxycarbonyl-β-carboline (2), along with five known, macusine B (3), vinorine (4), undulifoline (5), isoresrpiline (6) and rescinnamine (7) were isolated from the bark of Rauvolfia reflexa. Cholinesterase inhibitory assay and mol. docking were performed to get insight of the inhibitory activity and mol. interactions of the compds. The compds. showed good to moderate cholinesterase inhibitory activity with IC50 values in the range of 8.06 to 73.23 μM. Compd. 7 was found to be the most potent inhibitor of both acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE). Compds. 1, 2, 5 and 6 were found to be selective towards BChE, while compds. 3, 4 and 7 were dual inhibitors, having almost equal inhibitory activity on both AChE and BChE. Mol. docking revealed that compds. 6 and 7 interacted differently on AChE and BChE, by means of hydrophobic interactions and hydrogen bonding. In AChE, the indole moiety of both compds. interacted with the residues lining the peripheral anionic site, whereas in BChE, their methoxy groups are primarily responsible for the strong inhibitory activity via interactions with residues at the active site of the enzyme. Conclusion: Two new and five known indole alkaloids were isolated from R. reflexa. Among the compds., 7 and 6 showed the most potent and promising cholinesterase inhibitory activity, worthy for further investigations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVOrt7bL&md5=68b26792529b1b9a20d9a62e6dec3fe0

      Schott, Y.; Decker, M.; Rommelspacher, H.; Lehmann, J. 6-Hydroxy- and 6-methoxy-β-carbolines as acetyl- and butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2006, 16, 5840– 5843,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2006.08.067
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      6-Hydroxy- and 6-methoxy-β-carbolines as acetyl- and butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors
      Schott, Yvonne; Decker, Michael; Rommelspacher, Hans; Lehmann, Jochen
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2006), 16 (22), 5840-5843CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Studies directed toward the discovery of novel acetyl- and butyrylcholinesterase (AChE and BChE) inhibitors for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease were focused on β-carbolines (BCs). 6-Oxygenated β-carboline, e.g., I (R = H or Me), and β-carbolinium derivs. based on the serotonin template were synthesized and tested in vitro for their ability to inhibit AChE and BChE, resp. The carbolinium salts, in particular, which could be formed by intracerebral methylation of tertiary-BC prodrugs, showed inhibitory activity levels reaching those of galantamine, physostigmine, and rivastigmine.

      Yang, Y.; Cheng, X.; Liu, W.; Chou, G.; Wang, Z.; Wang, C. Potent AChE and BChE inhibitors isolated from seeds of Peganum harmala Linn by a bioassay-guided fractionation. J. Ethnopharmacol. 2015, 168, 279– 286,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jep.2015.03.070
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      Potent AChE and BChE inhibitors isolated from seeds of Peganum harmala Linn by a bioassay-guided fractionation
      Yang, Yadi; Cheng, Xuemei; Liu, Wei; Chou, Guixin; Wang, Zhengtao; Wang, Changhong
      Journal of Ethnopharmacology (2015), 168 (), 279-286CODEN: JOETD7; ISSN:0378-8741. (Elsevier Ireland Ltd.)
      Seeds of Peganum harmala Linn are traditionally used as folk medical herb in Uighur medicine in China to treat disorders of hemiplegia and amnesia. Previously studies have proved that dominating alkaloids in P. harmala show significant inhibitory activities on the cholinesterase. The aim of the present study is to isolate trace ingredients from seeds of P. harmala and evaluate its inhibitory activities on acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE). For sake of screening effective cholinesterase inhibitors, trace compds. were isolated from seeds of P. harmala through a bioassay-guided fractionation and their structures were detd. via detailed spectral anal. The inhibitory activities on AChE and BChE were assessed using an improved Ellman method by UPLC-ESI-MS/MS to det. the common final product choline. The activity-guided fractionation led to the isolation of two new alkaloids 2-aldehyde-tetrahydroharmine (10), 2-carboxyl-3,4-dihydroquinazoline (19), one syringin structure analog 1-O-β-D-xylopyranose sinapyl alc. (22), and along with 19 known compds. Compds. acetylnorharmine (6), harmic acid methy ester (7), harmine N-oxide (13), 6-methoxyindoline (14), syringin (21) were first found from genus Peganum and compds. 3-hydroxylated harmine (4), 1-hydroxy-7-methoxy-β-carboline (5) were new natural products. The results showed that the 2-aldehyde-tetrahydroharmine (10) has a potential inbibitive effect on both AChE and BChE with IC50 values of 12.35±0.24 and 5.51±0.33 μM, resp. Deoxyvasicine (15) and vasicine (16) showed the strongest BChE inhibitory activity with IC50 values of 0.04±0.01 and 0.1±0.01 μM. The anal. of the structure-activity relationship indicated that the satn. of pyridine ring and the presence of substitution at indole ring, C-1, C-3, C-7 and N-2, for β-carbolines, were essential for effective inhibition of both AChE and BChE and the five-membered ring between C-2 and N-3 as well as the substituent groups sited at C-4 and C-9, for quinazolines, were important to both the AChE/BChE-inhibitory activity. Bioassay-guided fractionation has led to the isolation of AChE and BChE inhibitors from the seeds of P. harmala. These results are in agreement with the traditional uses of the seeds of P. harmala.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXmsVajuro%253D&md5=36c095e788b3e9a3853f00252a32844f

      Arshad, A. S. M.; Chear, N. J. Y.; Ezzat, M. O.; Hanapi, N. A.; Meesala, R.; Arshad, S.; Mansor, S. M.; Mordi, M. N. Synthesis, characterization and crystal structure of new tetrahydro-β-carboline as acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. J. Mol. Struct. 2020, 1200, 127070,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molstruc.2019.127070

      22
      Synthesis, characterization and crystal structure of new tetrahydro-β-carboline as acetylcholinesterase inhibitor
      Mohamad Arshad, Ahmad Saifuddin; Chear, Nelson Jeng Yeou; Ezzat, Mohammed Oday; Hanapi, Nur Aziah; Meesala, Ramu; Arshad, Suhana; Mansor, Sharif Mahsufi; Mordi, Mohd Nizam
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2020), 1200 (), 127070pp.CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A new tetrahydro-β-carboline deriv., 2-benzoyl-6-methoxy-9-methyl-1-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-β-carboline was synthesized through a three-steps reaction in good yield (76%). The structure of this compd. was characterized by different spectroscopic methods including NMR (1D and 2D), UV, IR and MS. Mol. structure of the synthesized compd. was also confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction technique. Further, evaluation of in-vitro acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitory activity showcased the potential of this compd. as AChE inhibitor with an IC50 value of 26.52 ± 0.79 μM. In addn., this compd. showed minimal toxicol. profile at cellular level. Docking simulation illustrated a highly selective binding at peripheral side of AChE via hydrophobic interactions. In silico prediction of blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeation and ADMET properties of the compd. was also reported.

      Zhang, J.; Zhao, S.-S.; Xie, J.; Yang, J.; Chen, G.-D.; Hu, D.; Zhang, W.-G.; Wang, C.-X.; Yao, X.-S.; Gao, H.       N-methoxy-β-carboline alkaloids with inhibitory activities against Aβ42 aggregation and acetylcholinesterase from the stems of Picrasma quassioides
      Zhang, Jie; Zhao, Sen-Sen; Xie, Jun; Yang, Jian; Chen, Guo-Dong; Hu, Dan; Zhang, Wei-Guang; Wang, Chuan-Xi; Yao, Xin-Sheng; Gao, Hao
      Bioorganic Chemistry (2020), 101 (), 104043CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Nine new N-methoxy-beta-carboline alkaloids (NMCAs) (1a/1b-3a/3b and 4-6) and two known NMCAs (7 and 8) were isolated from the stems of Picrasma quassioides. Their structures were elucidated by spectroscopic data analyses, quantum chem. calcns., and single-crystal X-ray crystallog. data. An anal. of the 13C NMR chem. shifts of the N-methoxy groups in these NMCAs and 41 gathered known compds. reveals the phenomenon that the chem. shifts of all these N-methoxy groups are greater than U+03B4 C 62, which can be used to recognize the N-methoxy group rapidly. In addn., the acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and Abeta42 aggregation inhibitory activities of 1-8 were evaluated. Compds. 1, 2, 7, and 8 displayed AChE inhibitory activity with IC50 values of 14.9, 13.2, 17.6, and 43.9 microM, resp. Compd. 2 showed inhibition activity against Abeta42 aggregation with an IC50 value of 10.1 microM.

      Fadaeinasab, M.; Hadi, A. H. A.; Kia, Y.; Basiri, A.; Murugaiyah, V. Cholinesterase enzymes inhibitors from the leaves of Rauvolfia reflexa and their molecular docking study. Molecules 2013, 18, 3779– 3788,  DOI: 10.3390/molecules18043779
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      24
      Cholinesterase enzymes inhibitors from the leaves of Rauvolfia reflexa and their molecular docking study
      Fadaeinasab, Mehran; Hadi, A. Hamid A.; Kia, Yalda; Basiri, Alireza; Murugaiyah, Vikneswaran
      Molecules (2013), 18 (), 3779-3788CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      Plants of the Apocynaceae family have been traditionally used in the treatment of age-related brain disorders. Rauvolfia reflexa, a member of the family, has been used as an antidote for poisons and to treat malaria. The dichloromethane, ethanol and methanol exts. from the leaves of Rauvolfia reflexa showed potential acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) inhibitory activities, with IC50 values in the 8.49 to 52.23 g/mL range. Further cholinesterase inhibitory-guided isolation of these exts. afforded four bioactive compds., namely: (E)-3-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)acrylic acid (1), (E)-Me 3-(4-hydroxy-3,5-dimethoxyphenyl) acrylate (2), 17-methoxycarbonyl-14-heptadecaenyl-4-hydroxy-3-methoxycinnamate (3) and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-1-oxo-β-carboline (4). The isolated compds. showed moderate cholinesterase inhibitory activity compared to the ref. std., physostigmine. Compds. 1 and 2 showed the highest inhibitory activity against AChE (IC50 = 60.17 μM) and BChE (IC50 = 61.72 μM), resp. Despite having similar mol. wt., compds. 1 and 2 were structurally different according to their chem. substitution patterns, leading to their different enzyme inhibition selectivity. Compd. 2 was more selective against BChE, whereas compd. 1 was a selective inhibitor of AChE. Mol. docking revealed that both compds. 1 and 2 were inserted, but not deeply into the active site of the cholinesterase enzymes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXlslCmsr0%253D&md5=0f3efe1f64254166cc04e20bbd42236c
    25. 25
      Abuhamdah, S.; Habash, M.; Taha, M. O. Elaborate ligand-based modeling coupled with QSAR analysis and in silico screening reveal new potent acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. J. Comput.-Aided Mol. Des. 2013, 27, 1075– 1092,  DOI: 10.1007/s10822-013-9699-6
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Elaborate ligand-based modeling coupled with QSAR analysis and in silico screening reveal new potent acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
      Abuhamdah, Sawsan; Habash, Maha; Taha, Mutasem O.
      Journal of Computer-Aided Molecular Design (2013), 27 (12), 1075-1092CODEN: JCADEQ; ISSN:0920-654X. (Springer)
      Inhibition of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE) has been shown to alleviate neurodegenerative diseases prompting several attempts to discover and optimize new AChE inhibitors. In this direction, we explored the pharmacophoric space of 85 AChE inhibitors to identify high quality pharmacophores. Subsequently, we implemented genetic algorithm-based quant. structure-activity relationship (QSAR) modeling to select optimal combination of pharmacophoric models and 2D physicochem. descriptors capable of explaining bioactivity variation among training compds. (r268 = 0.94, F-statistic = 125.8, r2LOO = 0.92, r2PRESS against 17 external test inhibitors = 0.84). Two orthogonal pharmacophores emerged in the QSAR equation suggesting the existence of at least two binding modes accessible to ligands within AChE binding pocket. The successful pharmacophores were comparable with crystallog. resolved AChE binding pocket. We employed the pharmacophoric models and assocd. QSAR equation to screen the national cancer institute list of compds. Twenty-four low micromolar AChE inhibitors were identified. The most potent gave IC50 value of 1.0 μM.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFWqu7zM&md5=5645f93992fc010575a355392c260d25
    26. 26
      Horton, W.; Sood, A.; Peerannawar, S.; Kugyela, N.; Kulkarni, A.; Tulsan, R.; Tran, C. D.; Soule, J.; LeVine, H., III; Török, B.; Török, M. Synthesis and application of β-carbolines as novel multi-functional anti-Alzheimer’s disease agents. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2017, 27, 232– 236,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2016.11.067

      26
      Synthesis and application of β-carbolines as novel multi-functional anti-Alzheimer's disease agents
      Horton, William; Sood, Abha; Peerannawar, Swarada; Kugyela, Nandor; Kulkarni, Aditya; Tulsan, Rekha; Tran, Chris D.; Soule, Jessica; LeVine, Harry III; Torok, Bela; Torok, Marianna
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2017), 27 (2), 232-236CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The design, synthesis and assessment of β-carboline core-based compds. as potential multifunctional agents against several processes that are believed to play a significant role in Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathol., are described. The activity of the compds. was detd. in Aβ self-assembly (fibril and oligomer formation) and cholinesterase (AChE, BuChE) activity inhibition, and their antioxidant properties were also assessed. To obtain insight into the mode of action of the compds., HR-MS studies were carried out on the inhibitor-Aβ complex formation and mol. docking was performed on inhibitor-BuChE interactions. While several compds. exhibited strong activities in individual assays, compd. I emerged as a promising multi-target lead for the further structure-activity relationship studies.

      N-Methyl-β-carbolinium Salts and an N-Methylated 8-Oxoisoguanine as Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitors from a Solitary Ascidian, Cnemidocarpa irene
      Tadokoro, Yohei; Nishikawa, Teruaki; Ichimori, Taichi; Matsunaga, Satoko; Fujita, Masaki J.; Sakai, Ryuichi
      ACS Omega (2017), 2 (3), 1074-1080CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      New brominated β-carbolines, irenecarbolines A (I) and B (II), along with 2 known β-carbolines (N-methyl-β-carbolinium and N-methyl-β-carboline-3-carboxylate) and a new 8-oxoisoguanine deriv. (III), were isolated from a solitary ascidian Cnemidocarpa irene. The structures of these compds. were detd. on the basis of their spectral data. All 3 new compds. inhibited the action of acetylcholinesterase (AchE). The activities of irenecarboline A and the new 8-oxoisoguanine deriv. were comparable to that of galantamine, a clin. used AchE inhibitor. I and N-methyl-β-carbolinium were present in high concns. in the blood, and fluorescence was obsd. in certain types of cells found in the blood of the tunicate.

      Rook, Y.; Schmidtke, K.-U.; Gaube, F.; Schepmann, D.; Wünsch, B.; Heilmann, J.; Lehmann, J.; Winckler, T. Bivalent β-carbolines as potential multitarget anti-Alzheimer agents. J. Med. Chem. 2010, 53, 3611– 3617,  DOI: 10.1021/jm1000024
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      28
      Bivalent β-Carbolines as Potential Multitarget Anti-Alzheimer Agents
      Rook, Yvonne; Schmidtke, Kai-Uwe; Gaube, Friedemann; Schepmann, Dirk; Wuensch, Bernhard; Heilmann, Joerg; Lehmann, Jochen; Winckler, Thomas
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 53 (9), 3611-3617CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a prevalent neurodegenerative disorder with multifactorial causes that requires multitargeted treatment. Inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) improve cholinergic signaling in the central nervous system and thus AChE inhibitors are well established in the therapy of AD to improve memory disturbances and other cognitive symptoms. On the other hand, AD patients benefit from redn. of pathol. glutamate-induced, Ca2+-mediated excitotoxicity by the N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NR) antagonist memantine. New drugs that simultaneously affect both cholinergic transmission and glutamate-induced excitotoxicity may further improve AD treatment. While connecting β-carboline units by alkylene spacers in two different series of compds. and subsequent evaluation of their AChE/BChE-inhibitory potential, we found that several of these bivalent β-carbolines were potent NR blockers. The most promising compd. was a N9-homobivalent β-carboline with a nonylene spacer, which displayed IC50 values of 0.5 nM for AChE, 5.7 nM for BChE, and 1.4 μM for NR, resp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXkt1Wksbo%253D&md5=0e0bb88f9dc3e023d9538cb186643cd4

      Peganumine B-I and two enantiomers: new alkaloids from the seeds of Peganum harmala Linn. and their potential cytotoxicity and cholinesterase inhibitory activities
      Yang, Ya-di; Cheng, Xue-mei; Liu, Wei; Han, Zhu-zhen; Chou, Gui-xin; Wang, Ying; Sun, Du-xin; Wang, Zheng-tao; Wang, Chang-hong
      RSC Advances (2016), 6 (19), 15976-15987CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Ten new alkaloids (peganumine B-I and two enantiomers), contg. five β-carbolines, three quinazolones, two compds. with both of the above skeletons, and one amphoteric alkaloid with a four-membered ring, were isolated from the ethanol ext. of Peganum harmala. Their structures were elucidated on the basis of spectral data using 1D and 2D NMR, X-ray crystallog. anal., CD, and ECD. Peganumine B showed potential inhibitory activity against both AChE and BChE with IC50 values of 0.25 ± 0.04, and 1.45 ± 0.34 μM, resp. Peganumine C, peganumine D, and peganumine I were found to have selective inhibitory activity against AChE with IC50 values of 14.38 ± 2.49, 5.71 ± 1.22, and 7.17 ± 1.45 μM, resp. Peganumine G and peganumine H showed significant cytotoxicity against a ZR-75-1 cell line with IC50 values of 6.20 ± 2.71, and 2.43 ± 0.79 μM, resp.

      Zhou, B.; Zhang, B.; Li, X.; Liu, X.; Li, H.; Li, D.; Cui, Z.; Geng, H.; Zhou, L. New 2-aryl-9-methyl-β-carbolinium salts as potential acetylcholinesterase inhibitor agents: synthesis, bioactivity and structure-activity relationship. Sci. Rep. 2018, 8, 1559,  DOI: 10.1038/s41598-018-19999-3
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30
      New 2-Aryl-9-methyl-β-carbolinium salts as Potential Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitor agents: Synthesis, Bioactivity and Structure-Activity Relationship
      Zhou Bohang; Zhang Bingyu; Li Xingqiang; Liu Xiuxiu; Li Hui; Li Ding; Cui Zhiming; Geng Huiling; Zhou Le
      Scientific reports (2018), 8 (1), 1559 ISSN:.
      A series of 2-aryl-9-methyl-β-carbolinium bromides (B) were synthesized and explored for anti-acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activities in vitro, action mechanism and structure-activity relationship. All the compounds B along with their respective 3,4-dihydro intermediates (A) presented anti-AChE activity at 10 μM. Thirteen compounds B showed the excellent activity with IC50 values of 0.11-0.76 μM and high selectivity toward AChE relative to butyrylcholinesterase (BChE), superior to galantamine (IC50 = 0.79 μM), a selective AChE inhibitor drug. Kinetic analysis showed that the action mechanisms of both compounds B and A are a competitive inhibition model. Structure-activity relationship analyses showed that the C = N(+) moiety is a determinant for the activity. Substituents at 6, 7 or 4' site, the indole-N-alkyl and the aromatization of the C-ring can significantly improve the activity. Molecular docking studies showed that the compounds could combine with the active site of AChE by the π-π or cation-π action between the carboline ring and the phenyl rings of the residues, and the β-carboline moiety is embedded in a cavity surrounded by four aromatic residues of Trp86, Tyr337, Trp439 and Tyr449. The present results strongly suggest that the para-position of the D-ring should be a preferred modification site for further structural optimization design. Thus, 2-aryl-9-methyl-β-carboliniums emerged as novel and promising tool compounds for the development of new AChE inhibitor agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MvktVOgsg%253D%253D&md5=a839c7da11fd0f399e884322059a92d4

      Five monoterpene indole alkaloids, mitradiversifoline, with a unique rearranged skeleton, specionoxeine-N(4)-oxide, 7-hydroxyisopaynantheine, 3-dehydropaynantheine, and 3-isopaynantheine-N(4)-oxide, and 10 known ones, were isolated from Mitragyna diversifolia. All the isolates were evaluated for their inhibition of acetylcholinesterase activities, and four showed moderate activities, with IC50 values of 4.1, 5.2, 10.2, and 10.3 μM, resp.

      Indole Glucoalkaloids from Chimarrhis turbinata and Their Evaluation as Antioxidant Agents and Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitors
      Cardoso, Carmem Lucia; Castro-Gamboa, Ian; Silva, Dulce Helena Siqueira; Furlan, Maysa; de Epifanio, Rosangela; Pinto, Angelo da Cunha; Moraes de Rezende, Claudia; Lima, Joselia Alencar; Bolzani, Vanderlan da Silva
      Journal of Natural Products (2004), 67 (11), 1882-1885CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society)
      As part of our study on bioactive agents from Brazilian rainforest plants, two new glucoalkaloids, 3,4-dehydro-strictosidine (I) and 3,4-dehydro-strictosidinic acid (II), were isolated from Chimarrhis turbinata, along with seven known glucoalkaloids, cordifoline (3), strictosidinic acid (4), strictosidine (5), 5α-carboxystrictosidine (6), turbinatine (7), desoxycordifoline (8), and harman-3-carboxylic acid (9). The structures of the new alkaloids were established on the basis of comprehensive spectral anal., mainly 1D and 2D NMR expts., as well as high-resoln. HRESIMS. Alkaloid 3 showed strong free-radical scavenging activity against 1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) as well as pronounced antioxidant activity evidenced by redox properties measured by ElCD-HPLC. Addnl., alkaloids 1-9 were submitted to TLC screening for acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Both 7 and 8 were shown to be moderate acetylcholinesterase inhibitors at a concn. of 0.1 and 1.0 μM, resp. In an in vitro rat brain assay, 7 showed moderate activity (IC50 1.86 μM), compared to the std. compd., galanthamine (IC50 0.92 μM).

      Indole alkaloids of Psychotria as multifunctional cholinesterases and monoamine oxidases inhibitors
      Passos, Carolina S.; Simoes-Pires, Claudia A.; Nurisso, Alessandra; Soldi, Tatiane C.; Kato, Lucilia; de Oliveira, Cecilia M. A.; de Faria, Emiret O.; Marcourt, Laurence; Gottfried, Carmem; Carrupt, Pierre-Alain; Henriques, Amelia T.
      Phytochemistry (Elsevier) (2013), 86 (), 8-20CODEN: PYTCAS; ISSN:0031-9422. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Thirteen Psychotria alkaloids were evaluated regarding their interactions with acetylcholinesterase (AChE), butyrylcholinesterase (BChE), and monoamine oxidases A and B (MAO-A and MAO-B), which are enzymic targets related with neurodegenerative diseases. Two quaternary β-carboline alkaloids, prunifoleine and 14-oxoprunifoleine, inhibited AChE, BChE and MAO-A with IC50 values corresponding to 10 and 3.39 μM for AChE, 100 and 11 μM for BChE, and 7.41 and 6.92 μM for MAO-A, resp. Both compds. seem to behave as noncompetitive AChE inhibitors and time-dependent MAO-A inhibitors. In addn., the monoterpene indole alkaloids (MIAs) angustine, vallesiachotamine lactone, E-vallesiachotamine and Z-vallesiachotamine inhibited BChE and MAO-A with IC50 values ranging from 3.47 to 14 μM for BChE inhibition and from 0.85 to 2.14 μM for MAO-A inhibition. Among the tested MIAs, angustine is able to inhibit MAO-A in a reversible and competitive way while the three vallesiachotamine-like alkaloids display a time-dependent inhibition on this target. Docking calcns. were performed to understand the binding mode between the most active ligands and the selected targets. Taken together, our findings established mol. details of AChE, BChE and MAO-A inhibition by quaternary β-carboline alkaloids and MIAs from Psychotria, suggesting these secondary metabolites are scaffolds for the development of multifunctional compds. against neurodegeneration.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

All of the isolated alkaloids showed an inhibition of acetylcholinesterase activity in vitro.

      Geissler, T.; Brandt, W.; Porzel, A.; Schlenzig, D.; Kehlen, A.; Wessjohann, L.; Arnold, N. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors from the toadstool Cortinarius infractus. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2010, 18, 2173– 2177,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2010.01.074
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      36
      Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors from the toadstool Cortinarius infractus
      Geissler, Torsten; Brandt, Wolfgang; Porzel, Andrea; Schlenzig, Dagmar; Kehlen, Astrid; Wessjohann, Ludger; Arnold, Norbert
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 18 (6), 2173-2177CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and therefore prevention of acetylcholine degrdn. is one of the most accepted therapy opportunities for Alzheimer's disease (AD), today. Due to lack of selectivity of AChE inhibitor drugs on the market, AD-patients suffer from side effects like nausea or vomiting. In the present study the isolation of two alkaloids, infractopicrin (1) and 10-hydroxy-infractopicrin (2), from Cortinarius infractus Berk. (Cortinariaceae) is presented. Both compds. show AChE-inhibiting activity and possess a higher selectivity than galanthamine. Docking studies show that lacking π-π-interactions in butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) are responsible for selectivity. Studies on other AD pathol. related targets show an inhibitory effect of both compds. on self-aggregation of Aβ-peptides but not on AChE induced Aβ-peptide aggregation. Low cytotoxicity as well as calcd. pharmacokinetic data suggest that the natural products could be useful candidates for further drug development.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjtVCrsbo%253D&md5=e6074e77293490cea4b30a6a66f4e725

      Kashyap, P.; Kalaiselvan, V.; Kumar, R.; Kumar, S. Ajmalicine and reserpine: indole alkaloids as multi-target directed ligands towards factors implicated in Alzheimer’s disease. Molecules 2020, 25, 1609,  DOI: 10.3390/molecules25071609
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37
      Ajmalicine and reserpine: indole alkaloids as multi-target directed ligands towards factors implicated in Alzheimer's disease
      Kashyap, Priya; Kalaiselvan, Vivekanandan; Kumar, Robin; Kumar, Suresh
      Molecules (2020), 25 (7), 1609CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a multifactorial disorder characterized by exponential loss of memory and cognitive deficit involving several disease modifying targets (amyloid beta, beta-secretase, monoaminoxidase-B, and cholinesterase). The present study explores multi-target directed ligand approach using secondary metabolite reserpine (RES) and ajmalicine (AJM) obtained from Rauwolfia serpentina roots. Novel LCMS and HPLC methods were developed for identification and quantification of reserpine and ajmalicine. In vitro enzyme inhibition assays were performed to evaluate anti-cholinesterase, β-site amyloid cleaving enzyme (BACE-1) inhibition and monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibition, further analyzed with in silico anal. Anti-amyloidogenic potential was studied using anti-aggregation studies along with TEM and CD (CD) anal. In vitro neuroprotective potential against Aβ toxicity and anti-oxidative stress was demonstrated using PC12 cell cultures. Reserpine is a more potent dual cholinesterase inhibitor than ajmalicine (IC50 values of 1.7μM (AChE) and 2.8μM (BuChE)). The anti-aggregation activity of reserpine (68%) was more than ajmalicine (56%). Both compds. demonstrated neuroprotective activity against Aβ42 (92%) and H2O2 (93%) induced toxicity in PC12 cells against controls. Phytocompounds also inhibited MAO-B and BACE-1 enzymes in concn. dependent manner. Mol. docking studies indicated the strong binding of compds. to the catalytic site of targets. This novel study demonstrated that reserpine and ajmalicine as a multi-target directed ligand that have disease modifying potential for amelioration of AD.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXpvVChtr8%253D&md5=5a001e3547ff49a1c2aba1bef25943d4

Pharmacological effects of Catharanthus roseus root alkaloids in acetylcholinesterase inhibition and cholinergic neurotransmission.       38
      Pharmacological effects of Catharanthus roseus root alkaloids in acetylcholinesterase inhibition and cholinergic neurotransmission
      Pereira, David M.; Ferreres, Federico; Oliveira, Jorge M. A.; Gaspar, Luis; Faria, Joana; Valentao, Patricia; Sottomayor, Mariana; Andrade, Paula B.
      Phytomedicine (2010), 17 (8-9), 646-652CODEN: PYTOEY; ISSN:0944-7113. (Elsevier GmbH)
      The leaves of Catharanthus roseus constitute the only source of the well known indolomonoterpenic alkaloids vincristine and vinblastine. In this work we studied the biol. potential of the roots, which are used in several countries as decocts or hot water exts. for the treatment of a no. of conditions. The aq. ext. strongly inhibited acetylcholinesterase (AchE) in an in vitro microassay, an effect ascribable mainly to serpentine (IC50 = 0.775 μM vs physostigmine IC50 = 6.45 μM) as assessed with the pure compd. Pure alkaloids were tested for muscarinic and nicotinic antagonism using rat ex-vivo prepns., namely, ileum and diaphragm/phrenic-nerve, resp. Serpentine competitively blocked muscarinic receptors with a pA2 of 5.2, whereas the precursor ajmalicine up to 80 μM was undistinguishable from control, and catharanthine exhibited an unsurmountable muscarinic antagonism at greater than 10 μM concns. Nicotinic receptor mediated diaphragm contractions were fully inhibited by catharanthine (IC50 = 59.6 μM) and ajmalicine (IC50 = 72.3 μM), in a reversible but non-competitive manner, unlike the more potent nicotinic antagonist tubocurarine (IC50 = 0.35 μM) whose competitive blockade was overcome by a physostigmine-induced increase in acetylcholine. Serpentine up to 100 μM did not change diaphragm contractions suggesting reduced affinity for neuromuscular nicotinic receptors. Despite strong in vitro AchE inhibition, serpentine failed to restore diaphragm contractions upon submaximal tubocurarine blockade, suggesting that poor tissue penetration may prevent serpentine from inhibiting AchE in deep neuromuscular synapses in the ex-vivo prepn. To our knowledge, the present study is the first to assess the effect of C. roseus root exts., as well as of serpentine, ajmalicine and catharanthine on AchE. The results described herein suggest that the currently overlooked C. roseus roots may constitute a promising source of compds. with pharmaceutical interest. Moreover, given serpentine's potent in vitro AchE inhibitory activity and low cholinergic receptor affinity, it is conceivable that minor structural modifications may yield a potent and selective AchE inhibitor, potentially useful for the pharmacol. management of conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and/or myasthenia gravis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpsVygsr0%253D&md5=2d0d300f8e5a83038bd5ac869f4cf73f
    39. 39
      Bharate, S. B.; Manda, S.; Joshi, P.; Singh, B.; Vishwakarma, R. A. Total synthesis and anti-cholinesterase activity of marine-derived bis-indole alkaloid fascaplysin. MedChemComm 2012, 3, 1098– 1103,  DOI: 10.1039/c2md20076g
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      39
      Total synthesis and anti-cholinesterase activity of marine-derived bis-indole alkaloid fascaplysin
      Bharate, Sandip B.; Manda, Sudhakar; Joshi, Prashant; Singh, Baljinder; Vishwakarma, Ram A.
      MedChemComm (2012), 3 (9), 1098-1103CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A short and efficient two-step total synthesis of marine sponge-derived bis-indole alkaloid fascaplysin (I) starting from com. available tryptamine (1H-indole-3-ethanamine) was designed and the synthesis of the target compd. was achieved in 68% overall yield. A key step involved in the present strategy is tandem dehydrative condensation between ortho-halo substituted glyoxal with tryptamine followed by dehydrogenation. Fascaplysin inhibited acetylcholinesterase (AChE) in non-competitive manner with IC50 and ki values of 1.49 and 2.28 μM resp. and with 60-fold selectivity for AChE vs. butyrylcholinesterase. Mol. docking studies revealed that fascaplysin accommodates within a peripheral anionic site and inner linings of the AChE active site gorge.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Novel inhibitors of acetyl- and butyrylcholinesterase derived from the alkaloids dehydroevodiamine and rutaecarpine
      Decker, Michael
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2005), 40 (3), 305-313CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Derived from the structures of the alkaloids rutaecarpine and dehydroevodiamine (DHED), and the long-known acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor tacrine, resp., novel compds. were synthesized, including: 13-methyl-5,8-dihydro-6H-isoquino[1,2-b]quinazolin-13-ium chloride (I), (8Z)-5,6-dihydro-8H-isoquino[1,2-b]quinazolin-8-imine (II), 5,8-dihydro-6H-isoquino[1,2-b]quinazoline (III), 13-methyl-5,8-dihydro-6H-isoquino[1,2-b]quinazolin-13-ium chloride (IV), 5,7,8,13-tetrahydroindolo [2',3':3,4]pyrido[2,1-b]quinazoline (V), and N-(2-phenylethyl)-N-[(12Z)-7,8,9,10-tetrahydroazepino [2,1-b]quinazolin-12(6H)-ylidene]amine (VI), resp. In a first step to evaluate their possible applicability for antiamnesic therapy, the inhibition of AChE and butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) were detd.: compds., II, III, V, and VI are moderate or strong inhibitors of ChE, the latter two compds. show a 10-fold higher affinity to BChE. I is a moderate inhibitor of AChE showing selectivity towards this enzyme.

      Huang, G.; Kling, B.; Darras, F. H.; Heilmann, J.; Decker, M. Identification of a neuroprotective and selective butyrylcholinesterase inhibitor derived from the natural alkaloid evodiamine. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2014, 81, 15– 21,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2014.05.002
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      41
      Identification of a neuroprotective and selective butyrylcholinesterase inhibitor derived from the natural alkaloid evodiamine
      Huang, Guozheng; Kling, Beata; Darras, Fouad H.; Heilmann, Joerg; Decker, Michael
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2014), 81 (), 15-21CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      Two sets of carbamates based on the natural alkaloid evodiamine were designed, synthesized and evaluated as potential butyrylcholinesterase inhibitors. Although a set of carbamates of 3-hydroxyevodiamine is inactive both at AChE and BChE, carbamates of 5-deoxo-3-hydroxyevodiamine (I) exhibit much better potency with selectivity toward BChE. The heptyl carbamate of 5-deoxo-3-hydroxyevodiamine (I; R = heptyl; 11c) shows the best potency with an IC50 value of 77 nM and very good selectivity over AChE. ORAC and cell-based assays indicate 11c possesses pronounced antioxidant properties with 1.75 Trolox equiv. and strong neuroprotection even from 1 μM onwards. These combined activities might enable compd. 11c to be a potential candidate for treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

      Synthesis and evaluation of novel rutaecarpine derivatives and related alkaloids derivatives as selective acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
      Wang, Bin; Mai, Yi-Chi; Li, Yue; Hou, Jin-Qiang; Huang, Shi-Liang; Ou, Tian-Miao; Tan, Jia-Heng; An, Lin-Kun; Li, Ding; Gu, Lian-Quan; Huang, Zhi-Shu
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2010), 45 (4), 1415-1423CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      A series of novel rutaecarpine derivs. and related alkaloid derivs., 3-aminoalkanamido-substituted rutaecarpine (e.g. I) and 7,8-dehydrorutaecarpine, and 6-aminoalkanamido-substituted 3-[2-(3-indolyl)ethyl]-4(3a)-quinazolinones, were synthesized and subjected to pharmacol. evaluation as acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors. The synthetic compds. exhibited strong inhibitory activity for AChE and high selectivity for AChE over BuChE. The structure-activity relationships were discussed and their binding conformation and simultaneous interactions mode were further clarified by kinetic characterization and the mol. docking studies.

      Triazolyl tryptoline derivatives as β-secretase inhibitors
      Jiaranaikulwanitch, Jutamas; Boonyarat, Chantana; Fokin, Valery V.; Vajragupta, Opa
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2010), 20 (22), 6572-6576CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Tryptoline, a core structure of ochrolifuanine E, which is a hit compd. from virtual screening of the Thai herbal database against BACE1 was used as a scaffold for the design of BACE1 inhibitors. The tryptoline was linked with different side chains by 1,2,3-triazole ring readily synthesized by catalytic azide-alkyne cycloaddn. reactions. Twenty two triazolyl tryptoline derivs. were synthesized and screened for the inhibitory action against BACE1. JJCA 140 (I) was the most potent inhibitor (IC50 = 1.49 μM) and was 100 times more selective for BACE1 than for Cat-D.

      Pereira, C.; Agostinho, P.; Oliveira, C. R. Vinpocetine attenuates the metabolic dysfunction induced by amyloid β-peptides in PC12 cells. Free Radical Res. 2000, 33, 497– 506,  DOI: 10.1080/10715760000301041
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44
      Vinpocetine attenuates the metabolic dysfunction induced by amyloid β-peptides in PC12 cells
      Pereira, Claudia; Agostinho, Paula; Oliveira, Catarina R.
      Free Radical Research (2000), 33 (5), 497-506CODEN: FRARER; ISSN:1071-5762. (Harwood Academic Publishers)
      The cytoprotective effect of vinpocetine [14-ethoxycarbonyl-(3α,16α-ethyl)-14,15-eburnamine] was investigated on PC12 cells treated with the amyloid β-peptides (Aβ) for 24 h. Vinpocetine was shown to protect cells from the inhibition in redox status induced by exposure to Aβ25-35 and Aβ1-40, the maximal protection being achieved at a vinpocetine concn. of 40 μM. At this concn., vinpocetine blocked the inhibition of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complexes II-III and IV and completely abolished the depletion of pyruvate levels induced by toxic concns. of Aβ peptides. Furthermore, the accumulation of ROS in cells exposed to Aβ25-35 and Aβ1-40evaluated using the fluorescent probe 2',7'-dichlorofluorescin (DCF), was reduced in the presence of 40 μM vinpocetine. Taken together, the data presented herein demonstrate that vinpocetine protects cells from Aβ toxicity, preventing the generation of oxidative stress due to the excessive accumulation of ROS. This study suggests that vinpocetine can exert neuroprotective properties which might be of importance and contribute to its clin. efficacy in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease or other neurodegenerative disorders in which oxidative stress is involved.

      Zhang, Y.; Wang, J.; Wang, C.; Li, Z.; Liu, X.; Zhang, J.; Lu, J.; Wang, D. Pharmacological basis for the use of evodiamine in Alzheimer’s disease: antioxidation and antiapoptosis. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2018, 19, 1527– 1540,  DOI: 10.3390/ijms19051527
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      45
      Pharmacological basis for the use of evodiamine in alzheimer's disease: antioxidation and antiapoptosis
      Zhang, Yongfeng; Wang, Jiaqi; Wang, Chunyue; Li, Zhiping; Liu, Xin; Zhang, Jun; Lu, Jiahui; Wang, Di
      International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2018), 19 (5), 1527/1-1527/14CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
      Evodiamine (Evo), a major alkaloid compd. isolated from the dry unripened fruit of Evodia fructus, has a wide range of pharmacol. activities. The present study sought to explore the neuroprotective effects of Evo in L-glutamate (L-Glu)-induced apoptosis of HT22 cells, and in a D-galactose and aluminum trichloride-developed Alzheimer's disease (AD) mouse model. Evo significantly enhanced cell viability, inhibited the accumulation of reactive oxygen species, ameliorated mitochondrial function, increased the B-cell lymphoma-2 protein content, and inhibited the high expression levels of Bax, Bad, and cleaved-caspase-3 and -8 in L-Glu-induced HT22 cells. Evo also enhanced the phosphorylation activities of protein kinase B and the mammalian target of rapamycin in the L-Glu-induced HT22 cells. In the AD mouse model, Evo reduced the aimless and chaotic movements, reduced the time spent in the central area in the open field test, and decreased the escape latency time in the Morris water maze test. Evo reduced the deposition of amyloid beta 42 (Aβ42) in the brain, and increased the serum level of Aβ42, but showed no significant effects on Aβ40. In addn., six weeks of Evo administration significantly suppressed oxidative stress by modulating the related enzyme levels. In the central cholinergic system of AD mice, Evo significantly increased the serum levels of acetylcholine and choline acetyltransferase and decreased the level of acetylcholinesterase in the serum, hypothalamus, and brain. Our results provide exptl. evidence that Evo can serve as a neuroprotective candidate for the prevention and/or treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisVOrurfK&md5=4628ac3813d0bbd47f23b076108614dd

      Sun, Q.; Liu, F.; Sang, J.; Lin, M.; Ma, J.; Xiao, X.; Yan, S.; Naman, C. B.; Wang, N.; He, S.; Yan, X.; Cui, W.; Liang, H. 9-methylfascaplysin is a more potent Aβ aggregation inhibitor than the marine-derived alkaloid, fascaplysin, and produces nanomolar neuroprotective effects in SH-SY5Y cells. Mar. Drugs 2019, 17, 121– 135,  DOI: 10.3390/md17020121
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      46
      9-Methylfascaplysin is a more potent Aβ aggregation inhibitor than the marine-derived alkaloid, fascaplysin, and produces nanomolar neuroprotective effects in SH-SY5Y cells
      Sun, Qingmei; Liu, Fufeng; Sang, Jingcheng; Lin, Miaoman; Ma, Jiale; Xiao, Xiao; Yan, Sicheng; Naman, C. Benjamin; Wang, Ning; He, Shan; Yan, Xiaojun; Cui, Wei; Liang, Hongze
      Marine Drugs (2019), 17 (2), 121CODEN: MDARE6; ISSN:1660-3397. (MDPI AG)
      β-Amyloid (Aβ) is regarded as an important pathogenic target for Alzheimer's disease (AD), the most prevalent neurodegenerative disease. Aβ can assemble into oligomers and fibrils, and produce neurotoxicity. Therefore, Aβ aggregation inhibitors may have anti-AD therapeutic efficacies. It was found, here, that the marine-derived alkaloid, fascaplysin, inhibits Aβ fibrillization in vitro. Moreover, the new analog, 9-methylfascaplysin, was designed and synthesized from 5-methyltryptamine. Interestingly, 9-methylfascaplysin is a more potent inhibitor of Aβ fibril formation than fascaplysin. Incubation of 9-methylfascaplysin with Aβ directly reduced Aβ oligomer formation. Mol. dynamics simulations revealed that 9-methylfascaplysin might interact with neg. charged residues of Aβ42 with polar binding energy. Hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions between the key amino acid residues of Aβ42 and 9-methylfascaplysin were also suggested. Most importantly, compared with the typical Aβ oligomer, Aβ modified by nanomolar 9-methylfascaplysin produced less neuronal toxicity in SH-SY5Y cells. 9-Methylfascaplysin appears to be one of the most potent marine-derived compds. that produces anti-Aβ neuroprotective effects. Given previous reports that fascaplysin inhibits acetylcholinesterase and induces P-glycoprotein, the current study results suggest that fascaplysin derivs. can be developed as novel anti-AD drugs that possibly act via inhibition of Aβ aggregation along with other target mechanisms.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtlaku7nI&md5=1256cafb0cb9c6bc9b373ddb640390a1

      Guo, E.; Hu, Y.; Du, T.; Zhu, H.; Chen, L.; Qu, W.; Zhang, J.; Xie, N.; Liu, W.; Feng, F.; Xu, J. Effects of Picrasma quassioides and its active constituents on Alzheimer’s disease in vitro and in vivo. Bioorg. Chem. 2019, 92, 103258– 103266,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioorg.2019.103258
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Effects of Picrasma quassioides and its active constituents on Alzheimer's disease in vitro and in vivo
      Guo, Eryan; Hu, Yunwei; Du, Tao; Zhu, Huilin; Chen, Lei; Qu, Wei; Zhang, Jie; Xie, Ning; Liu, Wenyuan; Feng, Feng; Xu, Jian
      Bioorganic Chemistry (2019), 92 (), 103258CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Alzheimer disease (AD), a prevalent neurodegenerative disorder, is one of the leading causes of dementia. However, there is no effective drug for this disease to date. Picrasma quassioides (D.Don) Benn, a Chinese traditional medicine, was used mainly for the treatment of inflammation, fever, microbial infection and dysentery. In this paper, we reported that the EtOAc ext. of Picrasma quassioides stems showed potential neuroprotective activities in L-glutamate-stimulated PC12 and Aβ25-35-stimulated SH-SY5Y cell models, as well as improved memory and cognitive abilities in AD mice induced by amyloid-β peptide. Moreover, it was revealed that the anti-AD mechanism was related to suppressing neuroinflammatory and reducing Aβ1-42 deposition using ELISA assay kits. To clarify the active components of the EtOAc ext. of Picrasma quassioides stems, a systematic phytochem. study led to isolate and identify six β-carboline alkaloids (1-6), seven canthin-6-one alkaloids (7-13), and five quassinoids (14-18). Among them, four β-carbolines (1-3, and 6) and six canthin-6-ones (7-11, and 13) exhibited potential neuroprotective activities in vitro. Based on these date, the structure-activity relationships of alkaloids were discussed. Furthermore, mol. docking expts. showed that compds. 2 and 3 have high affinity for both of dual-specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A (DYPKIA) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Tau protein kinases: Involvement in Alzheimer's disease
      Martin, Ludovic; Latypova, Xenia; Wilson, Cornelia M.; Magnaudeix, Amandine; Perrin, Marie-Laure; Yardin, Catherine; Terro, Faraj
      Ageing Research Reviews (2013), 12 (1), 289-309CODEN: ARRGAK; ISSN:1568-1637. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Tau phosphorylation is regulated by a balance between tau kinase and phosphatase activities. Disruption of this equil. was suggested to be at the origin of abnormal tau phosphorylation and thereby might contribute to tau aggregation. Thus, understanding the regulation modes of tau phosphorylation is of high interest in detg. the possible causes at the origin of the formation of tau aggregates in order to elaborate protection strategies to cope with these lesions in Alzheimer's disease. Among the possible and specific interventions that reverse tau phosphorylation is the inhibition of certain tau kinases. Here, we extensively reviewed tau protein kinases, their physiol. roles and regulation, their involvement in tau phosphorylation and their relevance to AD. We also reviewed the most common inhibitory compds. acting on each tau kinase.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtFKmt7w%253D&md5=ce41a1cf982105ec7b3cc0ee6fcdf20b

      Frost, D.; Meechoovet, B.; Wang, T.; Gately, S.; Giorgetti, M.; Shcherbakova, I.; Dunckley, T. β-Carboline compounds, including harmine, inhibit DYRK1A and tau phosphorylation at multiple Alzheimer’s disease-related sites. PLoS One 2011, 6, e19264  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0019264
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      β-Carboline compounds, including harmine, inhibit DYRK1A and tau phosphorylation at multiple Alzheimer's disease-related sites
      Frost, Danielle; Meechoovet, Bessie; Wang, Tong; Gately, Stephen; Giorgetti, Marco; Shcherbakova, Irina; Dunckley, Travis
      PLoS One (2011), 6 (5), e19264CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      Harmine, a β-carboline alkaloid, is a high affinity inhibitor of the dual specificity tyrosine phosphorylation regulated kinase 1A (DYRK1A) protein. The DYRK1A gene is located within the Down Syndrome Crit. Region (DSCR) on chromosome 21. We and others have implicated DYRK1A in the phosphorylation of tau protein on multiple sites assocd. with tau pathol. in Down Syndrome and in Alzheimer's disease (AD). Pharmacol. inhibition of this kinase may provide an opportunity to intervene therapeutically to alter the onset or progression of tau pathol. in AD. Here we test the ability of harmine, and numerous addnl. β-carboline compds., to inhibit the DYRK1A dependent phosphorylation of tau protein on serine 396, serine 262/serine 356 (12E8 epitope), and threonine 231 in cell culture assays and in vitro phosphorylation assays. Results demonstrate that the β-carboline compds. (1) potently reduce the expression of all three phosphorylated forms of tau protein, and (2) inhibit the DYRK1A catalyzed direct phosphorylation of tau protein on serine 396. By assaying several β-carboline compds., we define certain chem. groups that modulate the affinity of this class of compds. for inhibition of tau phosphorylation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmtFKjurY%253D&md5=586705088397bfee8f58955b94bcc1db

      Adayev, T.; Wegiel, J.; Hwang, Y.-W. Harmine is an ATP-competitive inhibitor for dual-specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A (Dyrk1A). Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2011, 507, 212– 218,  DOI: 10.1016/j.abb.2010.12.024
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      50
      Harmine is an ATP-competitive inhibitor for dual-specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A (Dyrk1A)
      Adayev, Tatyana; Wegiel, Jerzy; Hwang, Yu-Wen
      Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics (2011), 507 (2), 212-218CODEN: ABBIA4; ISSN:0003-9861. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Harmine is a β-carboline alkaloid. The compd. is a potent inhibitor of dual-specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A (Dyrk1A), a kinase implicated in Down syndrome. In this study, we show that harmine functions as an ATP-competitive inhibitor against Dyrk1A. Our conclusion is supported by kinetic anal. of harmine inhibition as well as by the characterization of a Dyrk1A mutation conferring significant resistance to harmine. The mutation, V306A, is located next to the highly conserved D307 residue in kinases known to coordinate the phosphate groups of ATP through a Mg2+ ion. The V306A mutation offers harmine resistance by differentially altering Dyrk1A affinity for harmine and ATP. The V306A mutation causes no apparent alteration to Dyrk1A activity except for the redn. in ATP affinity. This deficiency could be fully compensated by supplying ATP with a concn. in the physiol. range. Our results reveal that harmine inhibits Dyrk1A activity by interacting with residues in the ATP-binding pocket and displacing ATP. Our results also suggest that harmine will be a good lead compd. for further designing of selective ATP-competitive Dyrk1A inhibitors through exploration of the ATP-binding pocket of Dyrk1A.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXit12jsbo%253D&md5=bd3cd9608d332bc43b5b04f56059b62e
